description: Borrowed from Middle French impost, itself borrowed or adapted from Latin impōsitus, past participle of impōnō (“I impose”).

entries.meaning: (chiefly historical) A tax, tariff or duty that is imposed, especially on merchandise.
examples: […]  a duty upon commodities checks itself; and a prince will soon find, that an encrease of the impost is no encrease of his revenue.

entries.meaning: (horse racing, slang) The weight that must be carried by a horse in a race, the handicap.

description: From Italian imposta, from Latin imposta.

entries.meaning: (architecture) The top part of a column, pillar, pier, wall, etc. that supports an arch.
examples: The outer circle [of Stonehenge] has been formed by a combination of two uprights and an impost; yet each combination of these three stones is detached, and without any connection with the rest, except that of coinciding in the form of a circle.
